instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.R7121: What is R7121? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.Q7010: What is Q7010? Q7010 controls whether or not PPDCIN_G3H will be let through to the PP3V42_G3H power supply, often this circuit area is not working because D7010 has died or corroded. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> charging with 85w only
threads.message:
This board works fine with 85w charger and charge fine  but when switch to 
45w charger show light on the charger  then  go off .
tried different 45 w but same result .
assuming there something wrong with PP3v42-g3h ?

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> charging with 85w only
threads.message:
Any chance the 85W charger is a fake?

Sounds like it has issues communicating with the charger. Does swapping I/O boards resolve the issue? I/O Cable looking ok as well?
Does the system still detect the charger or not? If it does detect the charger, does it charge the battery from it without the light working?

Just running through the basics before we're digging into circuits

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> charging with 85w only
threads.message:
We use only original apple charger 
replaced the I/o board flex cable too not charging with 45w no light on the charger and not charging the battery .
but charge with 85w and now tired 60w it is charging .
i found the <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR> missing , soldered new one but still same issue .
not sure if the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is the issue .

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> charging with 85w only
threads.message:
Check all components around <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR>.
It happened for me with 00164 and found corrosion there...

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> charging with 85w only
threads.message:
Just to be sure, the 45W doesn't get detected by the system at all? Or does it simply just not charge with the 45W?

Voltage of <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> with the 45W charger connected?

If its charging with 60W+ chargers I doubt <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> itself is the culpit, I would suspect the SMC the most but even that woudn't explain why it does charge over 60W and 85W chargers. The only difference between those chargers is the voltage slightly...

Does the board look OK physically? Any history?

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> charging with 85w only
threads.message:
I just remembered.
In my case, <RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR> found degraded to 10k, because of corrosion.
45W charger went to protection mode, no magsafe light at all...

It was charging and working good with 60W and 85W charger too.

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> charging with 85w only
threads.message:
2informaticos , you are right , the 45w charger goes to protection status and to use it again even with good working laptop 
I must unplug it from the outlet then plug again 
but I checked around <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> there no corrosion around 
and looks clean no burn or damaged chipset.
replaced the <RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR> which gives 68k but still same result .:(:(

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> charging with 85w only
threads.message:
Measure all the components in that area.
Get voltages with 60/85W charger connected, that can help.
